item.title: By: Anon

item.description:

item.title: By: Foton of AFK Gamer
item.dc:creator: Foton of AFK Gamer
item.description:
I think the large problem was locking the accounts while they were investigating. Even 5 minutes of thought would have told them there could be many benign reasons that a character (and a low-level one at that) would accumulate large amounts of game currency.
Locking first, asking questions later puts the onus on the player to seek restoration of his account (for which HE IS PAYING) -- the appeals process is virtually nonexistent.
Of course we all make mistakes, but repeated gross errors in judgement is quite another thing. Not every cheater can be caught with algorithms and data traps.

item.title: By: bloo
item.dc:creator: bloo
item.content:encoded:
This is fear, pure and simple – “the little-death that brings total obliteration.”

Blizzard has let its fear of what might happen destroy their ability to manage the game well and make well-reasoned decisions. There are good reasons for some fears. And the way to address them is though innovative and intelligent game design choices. But they haven’t really made any game design choices. They are following in the footsteps of others, i.e., ‘being a better Everquest’, and thus are afraid of all the things they perceive as problems in other games.

item.title: By: Foton of AFK Gamer

item.description:
Thanks Wreak for the update on the first link. The 2nd link was resolved thusly:
I wanted to clear things up a little. This account was specificly locked due to both excessive gold being stored on the account, and questionable behavior associated with the gold. Protecting the game economy is very important to us.
Maleki In-Game Customer Support Manager
I know they'll never share what constitutes questionable behavior ... but wording the response so as to raise IGE/ebay suspicions is a nice touch.
